body:
@rabbah i want to pass some functions to openwhisk (maybe some rest call with credentials). in the action of openwhisk it can be called with some parameters.

is that possible?
Parameters passed between actions are json objects - you have to serialize values otherwise it will be work. You can send a function as a string and eval it in some other action to run it.
@csantanapr I reorganized the docs taking your input into account.
@jeremiaswerner you'll need to rebase and resolve conflicts for this branch.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/5ace5077581aa75ad349ef33a2acb9fc1730ccfc.
If they haven't it's fixable by editing the .wskprops file.
@csantanapr  thanks for the PR

Kudos - this is an excellent improvement which will greatly extend OW's possible use cases.

The one thing I somewhat stumbled over is that the current proposal's "web-export" annotations seem to mix orthogonal concerns, in particular billing vs functional concerns (headers etc). Could we take the "anon access" out of "web-export" and make it an explicit annotation?

btw: the way I read it, a package can be _both_ "meta" *and* "web-export" (so that shared libraries producing HTML are possible). Right?

> Could we take the "anon access" out of "web-export" and make it an explicit annotation?

Great observation - Yes indeed. I considered this to be part of moving this code out of "experimental" - these features can be made available to existing mainline invokes for sure. In the future enhancement section of the doc, I added one way to do that wrt authentication vs anonymous.

> a package can be both "meta" and "web-export"

Yes it's possible to fix - although I think by extending the web actions annotations, it's questionable if we need the meta approach (they can be subsumed by web actions). It's just that historically I added meta first, and then generalized for web.

Great thought provoking feedback - thank you!
pretty much thought the same as @jthomas - would like to add that the approach sketched by him also works for composites other than sequences once we get to those.

The approached sketched by @jthomas is the same as the one for @starpit. This approach in general allows for composition. 

Nick suggested attaching the catch handlers via an annotation on the action. Another approach is to define in addition to "main", an optional catch handler as well. The latter has a nice property of colocating the handling down at the invoker level.
I think we could prototype this with a 'catch' combinator implemented at user-level using whisk.invoke() ,and then promote it to a full-fledged language feature after playing with it.
if we do a user-level catch, how would we put a catch around a "native" sequence?
@rabbah the "catch" method approach won't work for sequences, will it?

@starpit I'm imagining a user-level catch combinator that takes an action A (either a sequence or not) and an action C.   It invokes A via whisk.invoke.   If the result is abnormal, it invokes C via whisk.invoke and returns the result.

update: the message above if from the previous version of the cli. The new version produces this error message which is more informative but could be cleaned up:

```
error: Unable to parse action command arguments: File 'xyz' is not a valid file or it does not exist: stat xyz: no such file or directory
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```

Rodric, I thought a bit more about this - especially in the light of [this comment](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1793#issuecomment-277006734). IIUC the current proposal then developers would choose at _design_ time if an action is a "web-export" or not. From an _internal OW_ perspective that means choosing if the features described [here](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1783/files#diff-444445a530f5b36d76f58f15f9220f49R39) are enabled. But look at it from a _developer_'s perspective: it means choosing which HTTP clients to support - either browsers or non-browsers (IoT devices, curl, etc).
One could argue that developers know the intended usage and can make that decision at design time. But at least in the scenario in above mentioned comment things become tricky: would action "D" the one catching errors be "web-export"'ed or not? Would it depend on the annotations of the whole composite?
Rather than trying to come up with a proposal/solution for the complexity above, I have a more generic proposal (or at least question): can we make *all* actions "web-export"? What would happen if we did that?
The big advantage I see with this approach is that developers could consistently use the features you have [described](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1783/files#diff-444445a530f5b36d76f58f15f9220f49R39) in _any_ action they write - i.e. they would not have to make design time choices about the user agents that use the action.
Potential downside I see: adding semantic meaning to fields that are potentially used already might break legacy code (but I guess that could be managed through deprecation etc). Mabe there are other disadvantages I am not aware of.
WDYT?

The reason I put all these features under a separate API route is precisely not to worry about legacy, or how to resolve tension with the main line API at first. The web action features are orthogonal to the try-catch solutions and should be considered separately.

I would plan to promote the web actions related changes to the main line action activation in stages. For example, while we can introduce path projection for action invocation with a small change to the path matcher, supporting extensions will be a breaking change (if we require it on all activations, it's not backward compatible, and if we treat it as an extension when present, then it's also a breaking change since it might have been part of the action name). Allowing form data and query parameters is doable on the v1 API.

One approach I considered is to disallow extensions on the main API path but offer all the other features. Extensions would remain in effect only for web-exported actions.

What you're pointing out is that web-export currently implies a few semantic changes or new features that are conflated. They are:

1. anonymous vs authenticated activation
2. content type extensions
3. result path projection
4. query and form data
5. http caller context
6. error handling

I don't disagree with your insights that we should promote these features to the main API for action activation. It's just a matter of doing so in a deliberate order and considering impact on existing code. A v2 of the API could give us greater latitude and there are other reasons to forge ahead with a second rev of the API. That arguably is going over board, since as I noted above, several of the new features can be retrofit to v1.

Hi Rodric, thank you! However, I believe I was not very clear with my question/proposal (or I don't understand you answer :) )
What I meant was: IIUC the current proposal then a developer has to explicitly set the web-export annotation on actions in order to use web-export's features. I wondered if we could remove this explicit web-export annotation and give all actions the features that are currently associated with web-export-annotated actions only.
This question is basically independent from the migration plan - it is more a question where we want to land.

For completeness, let me also be a bit more clear on _why_ I ask this question:
Consider an app developer who writes an action that (depending on some application logic) produces either HTML or an HTTP redirect. Pretty simple. He can deploy that action with the web-export.
But the way it is currently specified, _only_ actions can be web-export-annotated. So, how should a composite like a sequence behave - which might contain a mixture of web-export-annotated actions and not-annotated actions? Would path projection for the whole sequence work?
I could think of different ways to answer/resolve this complexity, but the simplest one I could think of was to not have the web-export annotation at all - and provide the same feature-set to all actions.

> I wondered if we could ... give all actions the features that are currently associated with web-export-annotated actions only.

Yes we can - I suppose I didn't make that explicit (that we can and we should). I have been thinking about the "how" - taking it for granted that many of these features are useful for all actions.

> So, how should a composite like a sequence behave - which might contain a mixture of web-export-annotated actions and not-annotated actions? Would path projection for the whole sequence work?

In the current implementations, it's a matter of where the annotation is attached and how the action is activated. Really you should think of `web-export` as a feature toggle to make all the features accessible to the API nested under "experimental".

> I could think of was to not have the web-export annotation at all - and provide the same feature-set to all actions.

I think this is problematic - I don't know how to talk about this without talking about the how. Do we introduce a new API to invoke actions with these features? Do we fold it into the current API? etc.

In any case, what features can be added to the main activation API without breaking changes, will be migrated. At some point, I would also remove the `web-export` annotation in favor of a more first-class feature toggle.
along the lines of the chat we had yesterday -- could we make the http support available without requiring an annotation, while anonymous invocation requires it?
OK to be very clear: Yes we can. And we will.

cool, thank you. Referring back to your earlier comment:

> I think this is problematic

what specifically is problematic here (I *think* @michaelmarth essentially suggested the same thing as I did). Is it that he was suggesting to not have an annotation at all vs I suggested to still have it, but with a reduced scope?
Thanks, I'll add a basic test cases for it. @rabbah ,pls help review, thank you.

@csantanapr Thank you for the opinion.

Regarding `tweak-dockerhost.sh` script, unfortunately it does not work on docker for mac environment.

That script adds route rule for 172.17.0.0/16 network.
All the packets sent to some containers will be forwarded to docker machine.

In the docker machine, which is linux most of the cases, there is docker0 network, 
and it will properly forward the packets to a target container.

In docker-machine environment, docker-machine itself also belongs to container network.
It is a gateway(172.17.0.1) for container network.
So it can forward the packets to container, but in docker for mac environment, it is not possible..

I am looking for the workaround.

By the way, I can configure cli and CRUD/invoke of actions with 172.17.0.1 as an endpoint ip.
Is there any case of accessing directly to components with each container IP? rather than api(nginx)?
@rabbah thanks for the hint. I've resolved the merge conflict and rebased
@style95 Yes, tests will try to talk to components directly rather than through the API.
greenish PG2 1012
the PR above does not resolve the issue, it still occurs.
PGs greenish @rabbah @markusthoemmes pls finally review and merge.

```
[2017-02-06T12:00:51.104Z] [INFO] [#tid_13] [Invoker] sending initialization to container [...] [...] [192.168.0.4:8080] [marker:invoker_activationInit_start:935]
[2017-02-06T12:00:51.843Z] [INFO] [#tid_13] [Invoker] initialization result: ok [marker:invoker_activationInit_finish:1674:737]
```
The current design/implementation did not take into account using triggers as the API backend.  It's possible to relax this restriction though.
solution 4:   implement a lock per entity and enforce a sequential consistency model
@mdeuser please review
@mdeuser can you give it another review, and open issues for the none blocking review comments to be done later.

Thank you @dubeejw, seems I don't have rights to run PG now, I'll work with Vincent try to figure out.
@rabbah , I added a test data with current test case, is it sufficient? Thanks.

@markusthoemmes Thank you to let me know.
Let me clarify my query.

In both local/distributed environment, user can CRUD/invoke of actions.
In local environment, endpoint IP is 172.17.0.1 and distributed environment, it is host IP.
So if there is no case user should directly access to containers with container IP such as 172.17.0.X, it might work.

I am just wondering in which cases user/components are communicating with containers with container IPs directly.
As @csantanapr mentioned above, if this is really how it works in reality, it would be better for me to know the cases in order to find the workaround.

As per my understanding, user/components communicate each other according to the IPs in `whisk.properties` file.
So I just thought that if test cases also can communicate with the IP in `whisk.properties` file rather than container IP which is retrieved by `docker inspect`, it might work.

Code change looks good.
@csantanapr - review comments are still applicable; no new commits since the last review.  Issue #1817 has been opened to address outstanding comments.
PR #1730 fixed this issue; closing
Fixed by PR #1772; closing issue
Resolved by PR #1730; closing issue
Resolve by PR #1734/  Use `wsk api-experimental list --full` to see path, verb, and action as separate values. Closing this issue.

This is no longer an issue.  The `\` and `/` characters are now handled correctly
I've just helped another user who ran into this issue. I'm going to add a note to the client library README to call this behaviour out but I can imagine it's going to continue to trip people up.

This also seems somewhat related to #1728 -- in general we need to revamp how we initialize global state of all kinds.

I agree that defining _OW_API_KEY during init() for javascript actions seems like a good idea.   I can't think of any reason not to.

@csantanapr - Just confirming...  If this action were part of a package, the above proposal would NOT include the package parameters/annotation values, but only the parameter/annotation values directly associated with the action.

At some point, would there ever be a need to allow the action developer to prohibit a specific action parameter/annotation from being copied?  I suppose this would also affect `wsk action get` as well.
rebased and merged in d47e39fb61f3e970f569a37a8713ad342ac38825

Hi @style95 the network path is required because all the unit tests in 
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/actionContainers/

The user will never call directly to the containers for /init and /run on port 8080, this will be the invoker.
The tests are there to emulate/mock the invoker calling out /init and /run to test the different runtime containers and that they behave the expected way
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/actionContainers/ActionContainer.scala#L139
```
        val mock = new ActionContainer {
            def init(value: JsValue) = syncPost(ip, 8080, "/init", value)
            def run(value: JsValue) = syncPost(ip, 8080, "/run", value)
        }
```

I really would like to offer users and contributors to be able to run OpenWhisk on their macs with Docker for Mac.

I proposed that we create a new test suite in gradle for testing on docker for mac that exclude this test cases that are not possible to run because of the network constraints.
Something similar on what we have today for Travis https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/build.gradle#L30
```
task testOnDockerForMac(type: Test) {
    exclude '**/actionContainers*'
}
```
Contributors can use this gradle tasks to run all tests excepts those. `./gradlew :tests:testOnDockerForMac`
If they submit a PR Travis will run the tests for them (They always have the option in addition to run them locally with a ubuntu vm if they are working in that area of the code and to work locally)

And for other Contributors using docker-machine they can continue running the whole suite locally with `./gradlew :tests:test`
@rabbah @markusthoemmes What you think about proposal on defining a gradle task for docker for mac users?

@kerryspchang - try re-configuring your `wsk` CLI with a new auth key.  Log into Bluemix and then head over to https://console.ng.bluemix.net/openwhisk/learn/cli and issue the `wsk` commands listed in step 2.

@tareqmamari, you are missing a comma in the annotations for parameters. See`"bindTime":false"type":"password"}`. The CLI will no longer allow for invalid JSON to be used for parameters and annotations. As a result, the command provided will not work until the comma is added. After fixing the annotation, retrieving the action works properly.

@csantanapr, please close this issue.
Need to close/reopen pr to re-trigger travis build - directly rebuilding from travis is not working at the moment.
@csantanapr, sounds like this can be closed.
@csantanapr, this can be closed as a dupe of https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1489.
@csantanapr, I believe this can be closed as well.
@dubeejw

@mdeuser 
>@csantanapr - Just confirming... If this action were part of a package, the above proposal would NOT include the package parameters/annotation values, but only the parameter/annotation values directly associated with the action.

Correct, I would not copy parameters annotations from package, since this parameter values come into play at invocation time, also user could be copying the action into a new package, which could have a different set of default parameters set.

>At some point, would there ever be a need to allow the action developer to prohibit a specific action parameter/annotation from being copied? I suppose this would also affect wsk action get as well.

Correct, if the subject is using a key that allows him visibility to read that information, then there is no harm to allow them to copy that information.
This PR is superseded by #1818 @mdeuser working on it now.
@rabbah would you do the honors?
the point of this bug report was that, on linux, the CLI is adding the newlines. the input *has no newlines*

```
$WSK action invoke fuseki -b -r \
    -p query "`base64 examples/q-ds-1.rq`" \
    -p model "`base64 examples/ds-dft.ttl`" \
    -p lang ttl
```

note how the inputs are either a simple string ("ttl"), or base64-encoded files, which certainly contain no newlines

@starpit thanks for the pointer, so is still fails for you on linux on latest cli version?

@dubeejw Did you verify that it works on linux now? Also is there a test case that can cover this?
Since the input works properly on Mac, I suspect linux is converting those escaped newline characters into actual new lines when passing the information to the CLI.
Do we still want this functionality? If not, please close. If so, please merge the corresponding PR.

@rabbah I think this is good thing to add to the CLI, be able to copy all the metadata.

>The reason: we don't make it possible to delete a parameter from the CLI.

What's the concern here about deleting a parameter?

Merging this PR doesn't block us from offering a way to delete a single parameter in future update of CLI.
I think it would be good to have it in and merge #1662, lets continue conversation there, about the concern that @rabbah express.
i have verified that this is still a problem with the latest CLI
interesting: it appears that the `base64` executable tacks a newline on the end. it does so on both macos and linux, but, for some reason, the macos `wsk` CLI is resilient to this.

So we currently have a convention, obviously, that any action that returns a result with an "error" attribute is considered an error.

Seems clear that reserving the keyword "error" is a mistake.   Easy fix: use something like __OPENWHISK_ABNORMAL_EXIT instead.
Not to mention the action isn't returning an error property.

@ioana-blue assigned to you speculatively. This looks suspicious: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/controller/src/main/scala/whisk/core/controller/actions/SequenceActions.scala#L322

ok ... so the check to abort a sequence based on "error" arguably should not apply to the first method in the outermost sequence .... although I could argue the other way and claim this is working as designed.

I still propose changing the keyword as a better fix.
Should not apply to the incoming invoke parameters - they are not the result of an action. Why do we need to change the convention to abort the sequence? This strikes me as completely orthogonal.
it's orthogonal, ok -- but the current convention sucks so let's fix it as long as we're touching that code?

Well if we change it it seems quite a change. Now actions might return error or some other property if they are stand alone vs composed in a sequence?

Edit: if you're just suggesting that instead of "error" to indicate a failed activation and instead some other property name, and keeping the rest of the semantics then ok that's not as bad as I was thinking. But I don't see why error is a bad idea or warrants a change yet. But I think I misunderstood initially.
pg approved and all that good stuff?
of minor note: if we had a `catch` mechanism #1793, then i could have protected myself from this situation, by redirecting the user back to the origin page of my app.

This works as designed. There is even a test for it @rabbah see this:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/system/basic/WskSequenceTests.scala#L107

Note zero actions being executed in the sequence is tested in this line (so works as designed) @starpit 
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tests/src/system/basic/WskSequenceTests.scala#L113

I understand we need to change this. Some of the options discussed in this thread:

1. simply not apply the 'error' convention to the params of the topmost/outtermost action in the sequence
2. change the reserved keyword (while keeping the current behavior of checking whether the keyword is part of the incoming params)
3. change the reserved keyword and also do 1 above

Thanks for pointing out the test.

Changing the name of the error property really is a different point. As in if the (initial) invoke parameters contained the property, whatever it is called, should the sequence really not run?

I think this behavior is wrong or at the very least surprising - since it applies only to sequences. We should consider the two points separately (behavior if invoke time parameters specify the property for error, and name of the error property). Changing the name of the property to something less common is just hiding the behavior/making it less likely to happen in practice. It doesn't address the sequence vs non-sequence invocation semantic difference. I suppose we could disallow incoming parameters from specifying this property, as option 4... maybe?

Option 5 as alluded to by @starpit: provide catch and leave the rest as is - but also doesn't address semantic gap vs non-sequences.

I vaguely remember why we settled on this behavior/convention. I think we didn't want to treat sequences differently depending on where they appear wrt to other sequences/actions

E.g., `s -> a, x` , where a is an atomic action and x is a sequence. Under the current behavior, if the error property is received by s or x, no actions from those sequences get executed. 

In the new behavior under discussion, it makes a difference whether the error property is received by initial parameter payload or is received as payload from a return from a previous action in a sequence.

> in the new behavior under discussion, it makes a difference whether the error property is received by initial parameter payload or is received as payload from a return from a previous action in a sequence.

Or to put it differently, if the invoke time parameters are received by a sequence vs non-sequence (atomic) action. Since sequences are actions, should the semantics apply to all actions?
I can understand some kind of retval interpretation, but why would we ever have an inval squasher? In AX if A returns error then fine kill the sequence at that point.
@starpit I can imagine scenarios where the incoming params come from triggers through rules and then you can think of inval as retval.

Triggers don't have return values so I think I'm OK with that. If we insist they do, I persist: any retval of a trigger is just it's inval. And so we are back to squashing. Added on input, which we cannot do, because inputs may come from a world that does not obey our conventions. 

And why isn't rejecting a promise sufficient for indication of error and thus shirt circuiting. Why would we ever need to invent a convention for this.

> any retval of a trigger is just it's inval

That's how I think of triggers.

>And why isn't rejecting a promise sufficient for indication of error and thus shirt circuiting. Why would we ever need to invent a convention for this.

Not sure I get this part. It may hold in a js only world, but how does it generalize to polyglot world?
